This recording is a Shaw 10 television broadcast of the show Image India. It is hosted by Radha Padmanabhan, and features a clip of music from the Shanthiniketan-Sangeet as well as nostalgic or historical segments from the Shaw Image India library. These historical segments include Bharatanatyam dance, Indian classical music by Mrs. Wasante Paranjape and her Orchestra, as well as a vocal duet from a Raga Mala sponsored concert.

Introduction: Radha Padmanabhan (host); Advertisement for Radio South Asia, CKER 101.9 FM; Song from Shanthiniketan-Sangeet: unknown (tabla, vocal, harmonium); Nostalgic segments from Shaw Image India Library - Bharatanatyam dance: unknown (dancer); Hindustani Classical Piece in Raga Kafi: Wasante Paranjape (vocal, harmonium) and The Orchestra (tanpura, tabla, vina, violin, sitar, bansuri); Vocal Duet from a Raga Mala concert: unknow (vocal), unknown (tanpura), unknown (mrdangam), unknown (violin)
Recorder: Shaw Cable, Producer: Mr. Padmanabhan; Performer: Amar Amarnath (mridangam), Raji Amarnath (vina)

This is a recording of Amar and Raji Amarnath. They begin by introducing themselves, and their musical formation. After this they introduce their instruments and provide further discussion on the history of Indian classical music, both Hindustani and Carnatic. Raji Amarnath begins with elaboration on the raga, and then begins a song in praise of Lord Ganesh. This is followed by further commentary and more music.

Explanation of personal musical history: Raji Amarnath, Amar Amarnath; Introduction of the vina and Indian Classical Music: Raji Amarnath Amar Amarnath; Introduction to the mrdangam: Raji Amarnath; Discussion of Cartanic Performances: Amar Amarnath; Song in Praise of Ganesh: Raji Amarnath (vina), Amar Amarnath (mrdangam); Song in Raga {edit (?)}: Raji Amarnath (vina), Amar Amarnath (mrdangam);
Recorder: unknown; Performer: Regula Qureshi, Kathy Hansen (sitar)
Fine Arts Building, University of Alberta, Edmonton

This is a recording from a lecture demonstration by Kathy Hansen. She provides an introduction to the sitar, followed by a discussion of her three different phases of learning sitar. This allows her to explain about the institutional method of transmission, as well as as the Guru-Shiya (master-disciple) tradition. Intermixed with these explanations are musical examples, and she concludes with a solo sitar performance.

Intruduction: Regula Qureshi; Overview of the lecture and introduction to the sitar: Kathy Hansen; The learning process in three phases - The Institution, The Guru-Shiya tradition, Global Extension to the West: Kathy Hansen; Alap and Composition: Kathy Hansen (sitar)

This recording begins with a section of Indian Classical Music by Jayaram Chari (vocal) with an ensemble that includes tanpura, tabla, and mandolin. The music is followed by an interview with Jayaram Chari, where he explains some of the history of Indian Music including the time of British colonialism. He also explains the story of several significant poets. This is followed by several pieces, which Jayaram Chari explains, and then sings with a young woman, accompanied by harmonium and tabla.

This is a recording of a World Music Sampler featuring live music and dance from Canada and around the world. It also includes music and dance from the newly formed West African Drum Ensemble at the University of Alberta.

Recorder: unknown; Performer: Karim Gillani (vocal), Ojas Joshi (tabla), Akbar Kanji (keyboard)
International House, University of Alberta, Edmonton

This is the recording of the first part of a workshop about Sufi Music led by Karim Gillani. It begins with a DVD about Sufi music in general, followed by a brief history of the Sufi movement in the Indian subcontinent and introduction to genres of Sufi music. After these comments Karim Gillani introduces the chorus of a song, and the performers and audience sing together to experience Qawwali music. After this song, Ojas Joshi explains about Indian rhythmic cycles on the tabla, and some of the cross-overs between Indian classical music and and folk elements in the Qawwali. Next Karim Gillani explains the different schools of Sufi music and the Kafi genre, which they demonstrate.

Commentary: Karim Gillani; Sufi Music DVD; Commentary: karim Gillani; Allahu Allahu (Qawwali by Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan): Karim Gillani (vocal), Ojas Joshi (tabla), Akbar Kanji (keyboard); Rhythmic commentary and demonstration: Ojas Joshi (vocal, tabla); Commentary on schools of Sufi music and the Kafi genre: Karim Gillani; Kafi Song: Karim Gillani (vocal), Ojas Joshi (tabla), Akbar Kanji (keyboard);
Recorder: unknown; Performer: Karim Gillani (vocal), Ojas Joshi (tabla), Akbar Kanji (keyboard)

This is a recording from the second part of a workshop on Sufi Music led by Karim Gillani. It begins with a Kafi song, followed by some discussion by Akbar Kanji about how he became involved in Suf music. Karim Gillani continues the workshop with a discussion of the Ginan genre and various related celebrations.

This is the first of a series of recordings from the World Music Sampler in celebration of Rumi, an ancient Persian poet. Connections to this mystical love poetry flowed through the concert in the music as well as dance and poetry recitations. The concert begins with dance and recitation, as well as music by the Indian Music Ensemble followed by original compositions by Kreisha Oro. (Part 1 of 3)

This is a recording from the Indian music class with Amelia Maciszewski at the University of Alberta. This recording begins with a general vocal lesson where the whole class learns "Invocation to Durga" in Raga Durga. It is followed by the vocal class discussing Raga Yamen and Bagashri, with work in Raga Bagashri. The final section on the recording is an excerpt from the tabla class.

She explains some of the different musical styles to be presented during the Sampler. They also announce an upcoming concert of Indian and Persian music called "Cultural Bridges Through Music and Dance."

This is an audio recording of the 1999 World Music Concert celebrating Diwali. It begins with the sounds of a Kathak dance to herald Diwali, along with greetings from distinguished visitors and recognition of important guests. This is followed with performance by the Indian Music Class and their teachers. After an intermission, Regula Qureshi introduces the guest performer of the evening, Shujaat Husain (sitar) who performs in Raga Rageshri.

This is the poster for a concert of Sufi music by Karim Gillani (vocal) accompanied by Jasbir Jabbal (tabla, dholak), Akber Kanji (keyboard), Nadir Bellahmer (violin), Naveen Shastri (guitar) and Salim Moorji (percussion). The concert also included Middle Eastern Sufi music from guest artists Ashraf El-Assaly (voice, ud), Michael Frishkopf (nay, keyboard, vocal), and Steve Byrne (duff, a frame drum). The concert was put on by Dolly Bandali and Abdul Mardhani, and took place February 28, 2006.

video recording (DVD copy of VHS original)
Recorder: Katrina Campos, Performer: Ojas Joshi, Katrina Campos

This recording includes a couple interviews and some examples of modern application of the tabla in Bollywood Film and at a concert. The interviews took place between Katrina Campos and her tabla instructer at the University of Alberta Indian Music Ensemble. In the first interview Ojas Joshi discusses the traditional tabla teaching styles and gharanas or musical lineages. The second interview covers his personal experience as a student, teacher and artist. These interviews are followed by examples of modern tabla application with an excerpt from the Bollywood movie Devdas and a clip from the University of Alberta tabla students performing at a World Music Sampler. {edit (the excerpt from the movie is approx 4 min long, too long? does it need to be taken out?)}

1. Professor Ojas Joshi Interview (Gharanas and Their Respective Playing Styles, Traditional Methods of Tabla Teaching), 2. Professor Ojas Joshi Interview II (Personal Experience as a Tabla Student, Teacher and Artist), 3. Modern Application of the Tabla (Devdas: A Bollywood Film)

This is a recording of a Kathak dance performance put on at the Royal Alberta Museum Auditorium. It begins with the set-up and sound check. The performance itself begins with an introduction to the genre of Kathak dance, as well as artist profiles for Amika Kushwaha as well as her accompaniests. This is followed by a short introduction by Cassius Khan, and then the music and dance begins. In typical Kathak style, at times an accompaniest or Amika Kushwaha herself recites the bols or rhythms of the dance candence, which she then repeats through her footwork.
Set-up and sound check; Introduction to Kathak dance and Amika Kushwaha: unknown; Traditional Kathak Solo Recital; Tarana

The concert continues with music by the Indian Music Class, Flamenco dances, and music from the Congolese Choir before concluding with a Celtic Music Ensemble.

Fine Arts Building Unversity of Alberta, Edmonton

This is the recording of an interview between Danica Clark and Khadija Jethan. They discuss language, growing up as part of the East Indian diaspora in Kenya, Bollywood filmi songs, diaspora music recordings and Bhangra music in Edmonton. They also speak of Khadija Jethan's own training and experiences with music and Khathak dance.

Studio 27, Fine Arts Bulding, University of Alberta, Edmonton

This is a the first part of a recording of a mehfil, a kind of lecture demonstration by Uday Ramdas. It begins with a detailed introduction by Regula Qureshi, followed by tuning and a song of payer to Lord Ganesh. Uday Ramdas then describes some of the history of Indian classical music and provides an overview of ragas. This is followed by a discussion and demonstration of some of the tal, or rhythmic cycles and patterns. Afterwards Uday Ramdas performs with Amelia Maciszewski on sitar.

Introduction: Regula Qureshi, Ganesh Bandera: Uday Ramdas, Regula Qureshi (sarangi), Explanation of India's classical music history and ragas: Uday Ramdas, Discussion and demonstration of rhythm: Uday Ramdas (tabla), Regula Qureshi (sarangi), Punjabi Qaida (formalized tabla solo): Uday Ramdas (tabla), Slow and fast tempo solo: Uday Ramdas (tabla), Vilambit, Madhya lay and Drut lay (slow, moderate and fast tempo): Uday Ramdas (tabla), Amelia Maciszewski (sitar) {edit (spelling)}

This is followed by an introduction to the sarangi, and listening instructions, an introduction to the tabla instruments, and a question and answer session. Recorder: unknown, Performer: Shujaat Husain Khan (sitar), Regula Qureshi (sarangi), Amelia Maciszewski (sitar), Ojas Joshi (tabla), Rohan Bhogal (tabla), Mirav Parteli (sarangi) {edit (spelling)}
Studio 27, Fine Arts Bulding, University of Alberta, Edmonton

This recording is the first part of a series of workshops by Shujaat Husain Khan. It begins with introductions by Regula Qureshi followed by some comments by Shujaat Husain Khan regarding his gharana or musical lineage. He also discusses (and demonstrates) some of the innovations in gayaki or vocal style of sitar playing. This is followed by work on a short composition with the other instrumentalists, incorporating the gayaki style. He also encourages other members of the audience to join in with the vocal line. The teaching is in a traditional oral style.

Introductions and tuning, Comments and demonstration about using vocal techniques on sitar: Shujaat Husain Khan (vocal, sitar), Practicing short composition: Shujaat Husain Khan (sitar, vocal), Regula Qureshi (sarangi), Amelia Maciszewski (sitar), Ojas Joshi (tabla), Rohan Singh Bhogal (tabla), Mirav Parteli (sarangi) {edit (spelling)}
A Musical Look at the Guru System, Session IV, Part 1
Recorder: unknown, Performer: Shujaat Husain Khan (sitar), Regula Qureshi (sarangi), Amelia Maciszewski (sitar), Ojas Joshi (tabla), Rohan Bhogal (tabla), Mirav Parteli (sarangi) {edit (spelling)}
Studio 27, Fine Arts Bulding, University of Alberta, Edmonton

This recording continues a series of workshops by Shujaat Husain Khan. It begins with some technical set-up and tuning, followed by some comments by Amelia Maciszewski introducing the session, which she describes as demonstration "the guru system in operation," the informal process of learning where the students repeat what is sung by the instructor. Thus the workshop includes both playing, and question and answer sections.

Tuning and introduction, Work on folk-based composition: Shujaat Husain Khan (sitar, vocal), Regula Qureshi (sarangi), Amelia Maciszewski (sitar), Ojas Joshi (tabla), Rohan Singh Bhogal (tabla), Mirav Parteli (sarangi) {edit (spelling)}, Explanation of the teaching style: Amelia Maciszewski; Question and answer session

Studio 27, Fine Arts Bulding, University of Alberta, Edmonton

This is part one of a recording of a lecture demonstration by Uday Bhawalkar (vocal) and Manikrao Munde (pakhawaj) accompanied by Andrew Buhr (tanpura). It begins with a short introduction by Amelia Maciszewski, followed by a small dhrupad performed by the University of Alberta Indian Music Ensemble to welcome the guests. This is followed by Regula Qureshi welcoming the guest artists and tuning of the instruments and preparation of the mridangam through application of a flour paste. The musicians begin with a short {edit (what?)} followed by some comments by Uday Bhawalkar about learning music in India and practice techniques.

Introduction: Amelia Maciszewski, Short Dhrupad: Indian Music Ensemble, Welcome: Regula Qureshi, Dhrupad piece: Manikrao Munde (pakhawaj), Uday Bhawalkar (vocal), Andrew Buhr (tanpura), Comments on learning music in India and practice techniques: Uday Bhawalkar
Uday Bhawalkar and Manikrao Munde Part 2
Recorder: unknown, Performer: Manikrao Munde (pakhawaj), Uday Bhawalkar (vocal), Andrew Buhr (tanpura)

This is part two of a recording from a lecture demonstration by Uday Bhawalkar (vocal) and Manikrao Munde (pakhawaj) accompanied by Andrew Buhr (tanpura). It begins with a Dhrupad piece, followed by a question and answer section on various topics, including practice methods and the history of Dhurpad, women performers and others. The recording concludes with some comments of recognition by Regula Qureshi, followed by an explanation of pakhawaj preparation.
Dhrupad piece: Manikrao Munde (pakhawaj), Uday Bhawalkar (vocal), Andrew Buhr (tanpura), Question and answer section: Uday Bhawalkar,

This is a recording from the beginning of the 2002 World Music Sampler. It opens with some Japanese dance by Wakabakai, followed by some comments by Regula Qureshi. This is followed by the group Imagine, playing ambient and Latino music, an ending this segment with music by Fox Saxophone Alice, a local saxophone quartet

This is a recording from the third part of the 2002 World Music Sampler. It features folksongs from the lumber camps of New Brunskwick, Middle Eastern instrumental music and Country music by Tom Phillips.

Folksongs from the Lumber Camps of New Brunswick: unknown (vocal, guitar); Music from the Levant: Michael Frishkopf (nay, tabla or dumbek), Samir Husain (ud); Tom Phillips (guitar, vocal), Ryan Dick (accordian)

This is a recording from the second part of the 2002 World Music sample. It starts in HUB mall, as the West African Music Ensemble processes through the mall to the Fina Arts Building, where they perform Ewe music and dance. This is followed by a movement into Studio 27 where the Indian Music Ensemble performs.
Parade through HUB mall: West African Music Ensemble; Astiagbekor: West African Music Ensemble; Indian Classical Music: Indian Music Ensemble (sitar, tabla)

Studio 27, Fine Arts Bulding, University of Alberta, Edmonton

This is a recording of the first part of the 2003 World Music Sampler. After an introduction by Kaley Mason, it begins with some music by the Indian Music Ensemble. There is a performance by the tabla students, followed by the vocal students and a sitar solo. The next performance is Armenian sacred songs (pagan and Christian) in an atypical jazz-influenced style on saxophon, djembe and Brazilian berimbau. This is followed by a performance of drumming, singing and dancing from the West African Music Ensemble and the somewhat unorthodox Bluegrass music from Lonesome and Then Some with special guest Jason Summach. The final performance is by Satpanth Sufi that explores Ismaili and Sufi music from India and Pakistan.

Tala: Ojas Joshi (tabla), Indian Music Ensemble (tabla); Alap and Composition in Raga Alaya Bilaval: Wasante Paranjape (harmonium), Indian Music Ensemble (vocal, tabla, tanpura, bansuri); Vilambit tintal and Drut tintal in Raga Pilu: Cassius Khan (tabla), Meera Varghese (sitar); Armenian sacred songs: Daniel Schnee (saxophone), Dwayne Hrynkiw (berimbau, djembe); Gota: West African Music Ensemble; Astiagbekor: West African Music Ensemble; Bluegrass: Lonesome and Then Some - Anna Somerville (vocal, guitar), David Ward (vocal, guitar), Jason Summach (vocal, guitar); Sufi Music (Kafi, Qawwali and Ginan): Karim Gillani and Satpanth Sufi (vocal, harmonium, flute, soprano saxophone, tabla, guitar)

World Beat Meets Fine Arts! (1995) Part 1

Fine Arts Building 2nd Floor Foyer, Unversity of Alberta

This is a recording of the first Centre for Ethnomusicology Open House. It took place throughout the day in the Fine Arts Building at the University of Alberta. The event included students and community members performing music from around the world, including Canadian folk music, AfroCuban percussion, Ukrainian folk music, Alp horn music, and Indian music. Regula Qureshi introduced the various performers, and Fordyce Pier, the chairman of the Department of Music also gave some comments. (Part 1)

Irish Jigs: Lisa Nelson (flute), Angie Tarager (piano), Jim Cockell (fiddle); Introduction: Regula Qureshi; Turkish Folk Music: Brian Rose (saz); Afro-Cuban rhythms: Jason Sinkus and friends; Comments: Fordyce Pier, Chairman of the Deptartment of Music; Ukrainian folk music: Brian Cherwick (tsymbaly or hammered dulcimer); Swiss Alphorn music: Dr. Walter Meyer (Swiss alphorn); Sounds of India: Vinod Bhardwaj (bansuri, frame drum), Masood Ahmed (tabla),

Fine Arts Building 2nd Floor Foyer, Unversity of Alberta

This is a recording of the second part of the first Centre for Ethnomusicology Open House at the University of Alberta. This recording begins with a continuation of Indian music on bansuri and tabla, with the addition of the Ukrainian tsymbaly. It continues with some Alberta fiddling followed by some classical and light classical music from Pakistan. Additional music featured include Celtic harp songs, Japanese Taiko drumming and a Ukrainian folk ensemble.

Sounds of India fusion: Vinod Bhardwaj (bansuri, frame drum), Masood Ahmed (tabla), Brian Cherwick (tsymbaly); Alberta fiddling: Rod Alstat (violin), Olly Christansen {edit (spelling)}(guitar), Doreen Christansen (piano); Strings from Pakistan: Regula Qureshi (sarangi), Masood Ahanad (tabla), Brian Harris (tanpura); Celtic harp songs: Kerry Linn (harp, vocal); Japanese Taiko drumming: Emiko Kinoshita (Taiko drum), Jason Sinkus (Taiko drum); Ukrainian folk ensemble: Brian Cherwick (tsymbaly), Jason Sinkus (percussion); unknown (violin)

Convocation Hall, University of Alberta, Edmonton

This is the recording of a lecture demonstration by {edit (who?)}. It begins with an explanation by the of how an Indian music performance takes place. He explains Raga Bihag , and the different sections of his performance: Alap, Jor, slow composition (in vubak, 7 beat rhythmic cycle), fast composition (in tintal, 16 beat rhythmic cycle), and Chala. After some tuning they begin playing. {edit (who is giving the lec-dem?)}

Myer Horowitz Theatre, University of Alberta

The is a first of five videos of a Sufi music concert from South Asia and the Middle East. The concert begins with a brief video about Sufi music. It was written by Karim Gillani and directed and produced by Aleem Karmali with narration by Sofia Lakhani and Nawaz Husseinaly. This is followed by music by Karim Gillani and the South Asian Sufi Music Ensemble. Karim Gillani introduces each piece with a few comments, and at times the words are visible on a screen behind them.

Video about Sufi music; Ya hayi ya qayum (Aawwali): South Asian Sufi Music Ensemble; Mankuntu Mowla (Qawwali, Munqabit): South Asian Sufi Music Ensemble; Ab teri Mohabat lagi (Ginan by pir Shams Sabzwari from 13th century): South Asian Sufi Music Ensemble; Sufi song (by lal Shahbaz Qalandar): South Asian Sufi Music Ensemble

This recording is from the third disc of recordings from a Sufi music concert. It begins with music by the Middle Eastern Ensemble, led by Michael Frishkopf. It also includes the recitation of Rumi poetry and a Hindustani dance choreographed to a Sufi song.

Instrumental: Middle Eastern Music Ensemble; Subhank wa subhanak (Sufi song by Shaikh Mohammad Halbavi from Egypt): Middle Eastern Music Ensemble; Ya Rasool lahi Mohammad (Sufi song): Middle Eastern Music Ensemble; Talaa al badru Alaina men thaneyat: Middle Eastern Music Ensemble; Ya Rasool lahi Mohammad (Sufi song): Middle Eastern Music Ensemble; Recitation: Imran Mirza; Mahi yaar di garoli (choreographed by Usha Gupta): Jehan Mawani (dancer), Narisa Bandali (dancer), Sarah Virji (dancer); Intermission; Announcements;

Lal meri pat (famous Sufi song by lal Shahbaz Qalandar): Karim Gillani and Ensemble, Jehan Mawani (dancer), Narisa Bandali (dancer), Sarah Virji (dancer); Comments: Karim Gillani The is a video recording of a Sufi music concert featuring Karim Gillani and Ensemble, with Dr. Imran Mirza as the master of ceremonies. The concert also featured guest performances by the Middle Eastern Sufi Music Ensemble, the Edmonton Ismaili Muslim Youth Choir and several Hindustani dancers who performed several Sufi dances. The concert begins with a brief video about Sufi music. It was written by Karim Gillani and directed and produced by Aleem Karmali with narration by Sofia Lakhani and Nawaz Husseinaly. The rest of the performance features South Asian and Middle Eastern Sufi music. In many cases the lyrics are from famous Sufi poets from the 13th or 18th century. {edit (this # is for 5 dvds, is it correct? contents have been listed for dvds 1-3, does it all match?)}

This recording continues a Sufi music concert with a tribue to the thirteenth century poet Hazrat Amir Khusraw. The song is followed by a performance from the Edmonton Ismaili Muslim Youth Choir, a group of young women who perform several songs, including some contemporary Muslim pieces, in both English and Arabic.

Tori surat ke balhari (Qawwali by Hazrat Amir Khusraw, 13th century poet): Govind Pandompatam (vocal) Ojas Joshi (tabla); Comments: Imran Mirza; Bismillah-e-Rahman-e-Rahim (contemporary Sufi song by Yousuf Islam): Edmonton Ismaili Choir; Imagine there is no country: Edmonton Ismaili Muslim Youth Choir; I am gonna make: Edmonton Ismaili Muslim Youth Choir; Thank you Allah (by Yousuf Islam): Edmonton Ismaili Youth Choir; Comments: Imran Mirza.

Myer Horowitz Theatre, University of Alberta

This recording is from the fifth and final disc of a Sufi music concert. It begins with music by the South Asian Sufi Music Ensemble. While the texts were written by poets from the thirteenth to eighteenth centuries, the song styles range from Ginan to Bhakti Bhajan to contempory popular songs. These songs are followed by some remarks by Dolly Bandall and Abdul Mardhani who put on the event. The recording concludes with a famous Sufi song by the South Asian Sufi Music Ensemble and the dancers.

Sansoon ki mala pa simron pi ka nam (Bhakti Bhajan by Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan): South Asian Sufi Music Ensemble; Bulleya ki jana main kon (popular song by Junoon band from Pakistan, text by Sufi Bulleh Shah): South Asian Sufi Music Ensemble; Pir nachi ne (Garbi Ginan by Pir Shams): South Asian Sufi Music Ensemble; Comments: Dolly Bandali, Abdul Mardhani; Lal meri pat (Sufi song by lal Shahbaz Qalandar): Karim Gillani and Ensemble, Jehan Mawani (dancer), Narisa Bandali (dancer), Sarah Virji (dancer); Comments: Karim Gillani

This is the poster for the Friday concert for the University of Alberta's International Week 2007. The concert took place at Myer Horowitz Theatre, and featured musicians, spoken word, dance and circus gymnastics. The artists included Kinnie Starr, Kita No Taiko, Firefly Theatre, Nunta, Tango Showcase, Gumboot Dancers, Raghsan, and Sufi Music Ensemble with Karim Gillani.

This is a poster announcing a course on Bollywood music, part of the Indian and Pakistani music heritage. Taught by Karim Gillani, it was offered for $145 through City Arts Centre in Edmonton and ran from September 28 to November 23, 2008.

This is an announcement about a course on Bollywood music located in the City Arts Centre Fall 2008 Course Guide (p. 8). This coure was taught by Karim Gillani and ran from September 28 to November 23, 2008.

The is a video recording of a Sufi music concert featuring Karim Gillani and Ensemble, with Hasan Nazrali as the master of ceremonies. The concert also featured guest performances by the Middle Eastern Sufi Music Ensemble and the Central Asian Music Ensemble. The concert begins with a brief video about Sufi music. The video was written by Karim Gillani, directed and produced by Aleem Karmali and narrated by Sofia Lakhani and Nawaz Husseinaly.

This is the program for a concert of Indian music in celebration of Divali that took place on November 4, 1999 in Convocation Hall at the University of Alberta. It was part of World Music on Stage, an annual event held by the Department of Music and the Centre for Ethnomusicology. The concert featured music by the Indian Music Class at the University of Alberta, as well as guest artists Shujaat Husain (sitar) and Hermant Ekbote (tabla). The program lists the evening's order of events, and includes brief biographies of the guest artists. It also lists the members of the Indian Music Class.
